_header: Look well about ye that lovers be
Note:
For refrain cf. 4225; also cf. Tilley (1950)
XTilley, Morris Palmer. A Dictionary of the Proverbs in England in the 16th and 17th Centuries. Ann Arbor, MI: University of Michigan, 1950, B 541; edition without attributing source: Hammond (1927)
XHammond, Eleanor Prescott. English Verse between Chaucer and Surrey. Durham, NC: Duke UP, 1927, 413.
_description: Beware of deceitful women — six stanzas rhyme royal with refrain: ‘Bewar therfor the blynde etith many a flye’

CamTCC599.First Lines:
LOoke well about ye that louers belat nat youre lustes leede yow to
                    dotage…
CamTCC599.Last Lines:
…Nat cowde then wryte womans trecheryBeware therfore the
                    blynde eteth many a fly Explicit
CamTCC599.Attributed Author:
Chaucer (added to right margin next to line 1, by a later hand, f.
                    207)

CamTCC1450.First Lines:
Lokyth well a bowte ye that louers belet noȝt yowre lustys
                    lede ȝow to dotage…
CamTCC1450.Last Lines:
…lett passe ouer yn ese & let þe wynd blowBe ware the
                    blynde ettyth many a flye
CamTCC1450.Editions:
Robbins,  Rossell Hope,
                        ed.  
             Secular Lyrics of the XIV and XV Centuries.
         2nd ed. Oxford: Clarendon, 1955: 244, 290.

BLHar2251.First Lines:
LOke wele aboute ye that lovers beLate nat youre lustis leede yow
                    to dotage…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…Nat cowde write wommans trecheryBe ware therfor the blynde
                    ete many a flye
